text: Hurricane Donna was a Cape Verde-type hurricane. It happened in 1960. It moved across the Leeward Islands, Puerto Rico, Hispanola, Cuba, The Bahamas, and every state on the East Coast of the United States. Hurricane Donna holds the record for keeping major hurricane status in the Atlantic Basin for the longest period of time. For nine days, September 2 to September 11, Donna had maximum sustained winds of at least . Hurricane Donna was a very destructive hurricane. It made a lot of damage from the Lesser Antilles to New England. At least 364 people were killed by the hurricane. Over $900 million in damage was done (1960 USD).Edward N. Rappaport and Jose Fernandez-Partagas. The Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492-1996. National Hurricane Center. Retrieved on 2008-10-13. Because of its damage and the high death amount associated with the hurricane, the name Donna was retired. It will never again be used for an Atlantic hurricane. The name was replaced by Dora in 1964. ==References== Category:Hurricanes in the United States Category:20th century in Puerto Rico Category:20th century in Haiti Category:20th century in the Dominican Republic Category:1960s in Cuba Category:20th century in the Bahamas Category:1960 in the United States Category:1960s in Canada Category:Hurricanes in Virginia Category:Hurricanes in South Carolina Category:Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes Category:Deadly storms Category:1960s in weather Donna
title: Hurricane Donna
